# Intelligence Community Design System

> Use the UK Intelligence Community's Design System to create accessible, usable, and consistent capabilities for complex and specialised needs

# Docs

- [Talking about disability and needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/introduction/discussing): How to talk about disability and needs.
- [Accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility): This section introduces accessibility and how to design, build and test for accessible apps and services.
- [Alt text](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/alt-text): Follow our accessibility tips for alt text.
- [Accessibility Statement guidance](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/documenting/accessibility-statements-guidance): How to fill out and maintain an Accessibility Statement.
- [Accessibility Conformance Report](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/documenting/conformance-report): An Accessibility Conformance Report is used for accurate and consistent reporting of accessibility status in apps and services.
- [Accessibility Statements](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/documenting/accessibility-statements): Accessibility Statements are simple but important documents that are useful to everyone.
- [Documenting accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/documenting): This section tells you how to document how accessible your app or service is.
- [When to create and update](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/documenting/when-to-create-and-update): Keep your documentation current and transparent.
- [Digital Accessibility Policy](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/requirement): This section gives you an overview on how to meet our Digital Accessibility Policy.
- [Meeting the Policy](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/requirement/meeting-the-policy): This section is a summary of the Policy. Refer to the full document for full details.
- [Subtitling, transcripts and audio description](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/requirement/subtitles-transcripts-captions): This section tells you how to make videos and audio accessible.
- [WCAG standards](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/requirement/wcag): This section briefly introduces the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).
- [AG Grid theme](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/ag-grid-theme): How to theme an AG Grid component using ICDS styles.
- [Auditory needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/auditory): Hearing impairment means a complete or partial loss of the ability to hear in one or both ears.
- [Designing for accessibility needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/general): Every app and service you create must have a minimal baseline of accessible designs.
- [Accessibility needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs): When building apps and services, be careful not to assume everyone is like you.
- [Invisible illness](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/invisible): Invisible illness is an umbrella term for medical conditions that are invisible to others.
- [Neurodiversity](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/neurodiversity): People often think, communicate, understand or remember things in ways we might not consider.
- [Visual needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/visual): A visual impairment is a reduction in clarity or loss of vision that may be temporary or permanent.
- [Motor needs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/needs/motor): 'Motor impairment' means a partial or total lack of function in a body part, usually a limb or limbs.
- [Colour](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/colour)
- [Community](https://design.sis.gov.uk/community): The UK Intelligence Community Design System is a community effort endorsed across the UK Intelligence Community.
- [Links](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/links): Links need to be understandable by all users.
- [Coding for accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding): This section introduces some tips for making sure you code with accessibility best practice.
- [Link](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/link/code): Links can be used to navigate to different pages or sections of a page.
- [Link](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/link/accessibility): Links can be used to navigate to different pages or sections of a page.
- [Card (horizontal)](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/horizontal-card/code): Horizontal cards are containers used to display structured information or link to new information.
- [Card (horizontal)](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/horizontal-card): Horizontal cards are containers used to display structured information or link to new information.
- [Defining accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/introduction/definition): The word 'accessibility' can mean a lot of different things.
- [Introduction to accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/introduction): Many people who work for us are directly impacted by the accessibility decisions we make.
- [Angular](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/angular): How to use the components in an Angular-based application.
- [Install the components](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components): Install and use the UI Kit component library. Use React or web components to quickly build accessible interfaces.
- [Releases and versions](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/releases-versions): Our approach to releases and versioning.
- [Testing with Cypress](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/test-components/testing-with-cypress): How to test our components with Cypress.
- [Inclusive language](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/inclusive-language): Consider that what you write can have side effects even with the best of intentions.
- [Automated accessibility testing](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/testing/automated-testing): Use a variety of automated testing tools to capture as many accessibility issues as possible.
- [Section container](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/section-container): Use the section container component to consistently align content within an app.
- [Tree view](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tree-view/code): Use the tree view component to display hierarchical data, or provide navigation, within a tree structure.
- [Tree view](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tree-view): Use the tree view component to display hierarchical data, or provide navigation, within a tree structure.
- [Tree view](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tree-view/accessibility): Use the tree view component to display hierarchical data, or provide navigation, within a tree structure.
- [Data table](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/data-table/code): Use a data table to organise and display large quantities of related data.
- [Select](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/select/code): Select allows users to select one or more values from a list of options.
- [Testing the components](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/test-components): Test the UI Kit components within the shadow DOM using a testing framework.
- [Top navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/top-navigation/code): Top navigation sits across the top of the page. It includes the app name, search bar, main navigation and secondary links.
- [Side navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/side-navigation/code): Side navigation provides an app's main navigation and is fixed on the left-hand side of the app. It includes the app's name, main navigation and optional secondary links.
- [How to contribute](https://design.sis.gov.uk/community/contribute): Anyone can contribute to the Design System and UI Kit.
- [Multi-select](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/multi-select): Use the multi-select component to allow users to select one or more values from a list of options.
- [Multi-select](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/multi-select/code): Use the multi-select component to allow users to select one or more values from a list of options.
- [Accordion](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/accordion/code): Accordions are expandable and collapsible sections that are used to show and hide additional content.
- [Back to top](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/back-to-top/code): The back to top component helps people quickly return to the top of a long page.
- [Alert](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/alert/code): Alerts display a short important message in a way that attracts attention without interrupting the current task.
- [Badge](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/badge/code): Badges are attached to other components to provide an indication that something new is available, or that something has changed.
- [Breadcrumb](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/breadcrumb/code): Breadcrumbs show someone where they are in an appâ€™s hierarchy and provide a secondary method of navigating back to parent pages.
- [Button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/button/code): Buttons are used to allow or encourage people to take an action.
- [Card](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/card/code): Cards are containers used to display structured information or interactive content.
- [Checkbox](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/checkbox/code): Use checkboxes as part of a form, in dialogs and in control areas such as filters or settings.
- [Chip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/chip/code): Chips are used to filter and present data.
- [Classification banner](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/classification-banner/code): Classification banners are used to show the data classification (also known as protective marking) of an app.
- [Data entity](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/data-entity/code): The data entity component displays a group of related data in a consistent and easy to consume way.
- [Date input](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-input/code): A date input is used when gathering a specific date in a text-based format.
- [Date picker](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-picker/code): A date picker is a type of drop-down control that allows people to easily view and select dates.
- [Dialog](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/dialog/code): Dialogs are modal windows that interrupt the user's current task to bring something important to attention.
- [Footer](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/footer/code): Footers are placed at the bottom of the page and can be used for additional links not found in the main navigation.
- [Empty state](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/empty-state/code): Use the empty state component when there is no content to display. It provides a consistent way of communicating to people what to do next.
- [Hero](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/hero/code): A large banner found at the top of page used to introduce page content, provide key actions and add personality.
- [Loading indicator](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/loading-indicator/code): Loading indicators help inform users that a request is being processed. Circular and linear indicators provide flexibility in design.
- [Page header](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/page-header/code): A page header defines the top of the page content and is a consistent way to show page context, key actions and secondary navigation.
- [Pagination](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/pagination/code): Use the Pagination components to split large amounts of content into pages and navigate between them.
- [Popover menu](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/popover-menu/code): Use popover menus to place actions inside a menu that overlays other page content when opened.
- [Radio button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/radio/code): Radio buttons let people select a single option from a list.
- [Search bar](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/search-bar/code): The search bar allows users to search for information using keywords or phrases.
- [Section container](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/section-container/code): Use the section container component to consistently align content within an app.
- [Skeleton](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/skeleton/code): Skeleton loading states are representations of the shape of content that help inform users that a specific type of component is loading.
- [Status tag](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/status-tag/code): Status tags are short, clear and digestible ways to display the status of something on the page.
- [Stepper](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/stepper/code): A stepper is a visual representation of a user's progress through a predefined set of steps in a linear process.
- [Switch](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/switch/code): Switches are used to quickly toggle an option on or off.
- [Tabs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tabs/code): Tabs let users navigate between content within the same context. Tabs organise complex layouts by moving content into multiple sections.
- [Text field](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/text-field/code): Text fields let users input and edit text. Text fields capture a single line of text and text areas capture multiple lines of text.
- [Toast](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toast/code): Toasts give brief, non-critical updates about events that happen in an app. Toasts are sometimes called 'snackbars'.
- [Toggle button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toggle-button/code): Toggle buttons provide an action capable of indicating a state. They are commonly used for turning settings either â€˜onâ€™ or â€˜offâ€™.
- [Tooltip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tooltip/code): Tooltips provide helpful information when the cursor hovers over an element or when focus is applied.
- [Typography](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/typography/code): Use the typography component for consistent styling across typographical elements.
- [Date input](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-input): A date input is used when gathering a specific date in a text-based format.
- [Date picker](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-picker): A date picker is a type of drop-down control that allows people to easily view and select dates.
- [Badge](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/badge): Badges are attached to other components to provide an indication that something new is available, or that something has changed.
- [Button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/button): Buttons are used to allow or encourage people to take an action.
- [Page header](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/page-header): A page header defines the top of the page content and is a consistent way to show page context, key actions and secondary navigation.
- [Roadmap](https://design.sis.gov.uk/community/roadmap): Our roadmap shows an overview of recent work, current focus and work we have planned.
- [Select](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/select): Selects allow users to select one or more values from a list of options.
- [Date picker](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-picker/accessibility): A date picker is a type of drop-down control that allows people to easily view and select dates.
- [Data table](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/data-table): Use a data table to organise and display large quantities of related data.
- [Date input](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/date-input/accessibility): A date input is used when gathering a specific date in a text-based format.
- [Gatsby](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/gatsby): How to use the components in a Gatsby-based application.
- [React](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/react): How to use the components in a React-based application.
- [Svelte](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/svelte): How to use the components in a Svelte-based application.
- [Vue](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/vue): How to use the components in a Vue-based application.
- [Web components](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/web-components): How to use the web components.
- [Content style](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style): People read, understand and consume content in different ways. What we write should be understandable by all, regardless of how they work, think or interact.
- [Grammar and punctuation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/grammar): Grammar and punctuation are the building blocks of good writing.
- [Principles](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/principles): Use the four writing principles to help create engaging and consistent content.
- [Numbers, dates and times](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/numbers-dates-and-time): How to write numbers, dates and times consistently.
- [Voice and tone](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/content-style/voice-and-tone): Learn how to apply our familiar tongue and how to choose the right tone.
- [Why we built a Design System](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/a-design-system)
- [Styles](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles): This section introduces our style tokens, which describe how things look and feel.
- [CSS and inline styles](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/css): Follow our accessibility tips for CSS.
- [ARIA](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/aria): Follow our accessibility tips for ARIA.
- [Doctypes](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/doctype): Follow our accessibility tips for doctypes.
- [Document structure](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/document-structure): Follow our accessibility tips for document structure.
- [Headings](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/headings): Follow our accessibility tips for headings.
- [Semantic HTML](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/semantic-html): Follow our accessibility tips for semantic HTML.
- [Semantic layout](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/semantic-layout): Follow our accessibility tips for layout.
- [Tables](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/tables): Follow our accessibility tips for tables.
- [Titles](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/coding/title): Follow our accessibility tips for titles.
- [Contribution criteria](https://design.sis.gov.uk/community/contribute-criteria): The contents of the Design System must be of a high quality, meet user needs and always be accessible.
- [Accessibility Statement](https://design.sis.gov.uk/icds/accessibility-statement): Accessibility Statement for the Intelligence Community Design System.
- [Limitations of automated testing](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/testing/automated-testing-limitation): Automated accessibility testing is essential but it has limitations and only finds between 30-50% of accessibility problems.
- [Manual accessibility testing](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/testing/manual-testing): Manual accessibility testing can include keyboard, screen reader and documentation checks.
- [Accordion](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/accordion/accessibility): Accordions are expandable and collapsible sections that are used to show and hide additional content. 
- [Alert](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/alert/accessibility): Alerts display a short important message in a way that attracts attention without interrupting the current task.
- [Back to top](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/back-to-top/accessibility): The back to top component helps people quickly return to the top of a long page.
- [Badge](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/badge/accessibility): Badges are attached to other components to provide an indication that something new is available, or that something has changed.
- [Breadcrumb](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/breadcrumb/accessibility): Breadcrumbs show someone where they are in an appâ€™s hierarchy and provide a secondary method of navigating back to parent pages.
- [Button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/button/accessibility): Buttons are used to allow or encourage people to take an action.
- [Card](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/card/accessibility): Cards are containers used to display structured information or interactive content.
- [Checkbox](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/checkbox/accessibility): Use checkboxes as part of a form, in dialogs and in control areas such as filters or settings.
- [Chip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/chip/accessibility): Chips are used to filter and present data.
- [Classification banner](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/classification-banner/accessibility): Classification banners are used to show the data classification (also known as protective marking) of an app.
- [Data entity](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/data-entity/accessibility): The data entity component displays a group of related data in a consistent and easy to consume way.
- [Dialog](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/dialog/accessibility): Dialogs are modal windows that interrupt the user's current task to bring something important to attention.
- [Empty state](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/empty-state/accessibility): Use the empty state component when there is no content to display. It provides a consistent way of communicating to people what to do next.
- [Footer](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/footer/accessibility): Footers are placed at the bottom of the page and can be used for additional links not found in the main navigation.
- [Hero](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/hero/accessibility): A large banner found at the top of page used to introduce page content, provide key actions and add personality.
- [Loading indicator](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/loading-indicator/accessibility): Loading indicators help inform users that a request is being processed. Circular and linear indicators provide flexibility in design.
- [Page header](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/page-header/accessibility): A page header defines the top of the page content and is a consistent way to show page context, key actions and secondary navigation.
- [Pagination](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/pagination/accessibility): Use the Pagination components to split large amounts of content into pages and navigate between them.

- [Radio button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/radio/accessibility): Radio buttons let people select a single option from a list.
- [Search bar](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/search-bar/accessibility): The search bar allows users to search for information using keywords or phrases.
- [Section container](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/section-container/accessibility): Use the section container component to consistently align content within an app.
- [Select](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/select/accessibility): Select allows users to select one or more values from a list of options.
- [Side navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/side-navigation/accessibility): Side navigation provides an app's main navigation and is fixed on the left-hand side of the app. It includes the app's name, main navigation and optional secondary links.
- [Skeleton](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/skeleton/accessibility): Skeleton loading states are representations of the shape of content that help inform users that a specific type of component is loading.
- [Status tag](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/status-tag/accessibility): Status tags are short, clear and digestible ways to display the status of something on the page.
- [Stepper](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/stepper/accessibility): A stepper is a visual representation of a user's progress through a predefined set of steps in a linear process.
- [Switch](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/switch/accessibility): Switches are used to quickly toggle an option on or off.
- [Tabs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tabs/accessibility): Tabs let users navigate between content within the same context. Tabs organise complex layouts by moving content into multiple sections.
- [Text field](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/text-field/accessibility): Text fields let users input and edit text. Text fields capture a single line of text and text areas capture multiple lines of text.
- [Toast](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toast/accessibility): Toasts give brief, non-critical updates about events that happen in an app. Toasts are sometimes called 'snackbars'.
- [Toast](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toast): Toasts give brief, non-critical updates about events that happen in an app. Toasts are sometimes called 'snackbars'.
- [Toggle button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toggle-button/accessibility): Toggle buttons provide an action capable of indicating a state. They are commonly used for turning settings either â€˜onâ€™ or â€˜offâ€™.
- [Tooltip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tooltip/accessibility): Tooltips provide helpful information when the cursor hovers over an element or when focus is applied.
- [Top navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/top-navigation/accessibility): Top navigation sits across the top of the page. It includes the app name, search bar, main navigation and secondary links.  
- [Typography](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/typography/accessibility): Use the typography component for consistent styling across typographical elements.
- [Glossary of terms](https://design.sis.gov.uk/community/glossary-of-terms): A glossary of the most common prop/slot names used throughout the Intelligence Community Design System.
- [Side navigation layout](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/navigation-patterns/side-navigation-layout): Use the side navigation layout to quickly set up a page where the side navigation is the primary form of navigation.
- [Top navigation layout](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/navigation-patterns/top-navigation-layout): Use the top navigation layout to quickly set up a page where the top navigation menu is the primary form of navigation.
- [Toggle button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/toggle-button): Toggle buttons provide an action capable of indicating a state. They are commonly used for turning settings either â€˜onâ€™ or â€˜offâ€™.
- [Chip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/chip): Chips are used to filter and present data.
- [Navigation patterns](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/navigation-patterns): Navigation patterns are ready-made pages with built-in components to help get you started.
- [Figma UI Kit](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/figma): Reusable and flexible Figma components used to design, prototype and hand-off designs for apps and digital products.
- [Custom theme](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/custom-theme): How to change the theme colour of some components.
- [Next.js](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/install-components/nextJS): How to use the components in a Next.js-based application.
- [Typography](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/typography): Use the typography component for consistent styling across typographical elements.
- [Components](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components): Components are reusable user interface elements that help create consistent, accessible and usable experiences.
- [Dialog](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/dialog): Dialogs are modal windows that interrupt the user's current task to bring something important to attention.
- [Accordion](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/accordion): Accordions are expandable and collapsible sections that are used to show and hide additional content.
- [Link](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/link): Links can be used to navigate to different pages or sections of a page.
- [Empty state](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/empty-state): Use the empty state component when there is no content to display. It provides a consistent way of communicating to people what to do next.
- [Alert](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/alert): Alerts display a short important message in a way that attracts attention without interrupting the current task.
- [Popover menu](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/popover-menu): Use popover menus to place actions inside a menu that overlays other page content when opened.
- [Pagination](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/pagination): Use the Pagination components to split large amounts of content into pages and navigate between them.
- [Text field](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/text-field): Text fields let users input and edit text. Text fields capture a single line of text and text areas capture multiple lines of text.
- [Status tag](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/status-tag): Status tags are short, clear and digestible ways to display the status of something on the page.
- [Side navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/side-navigation): Side navigation provides an app's main navigation and is fixed on the left-hand side of the app. It includes the app's name, main navigation and optional secondary links.
- [Testing with Jest and React Testing Library](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/test-components/testing-with-jest-and-rtl): How to test our components with Jest and React Testing Library.
- [Documents Overview](https://design.sis.gov.uk/icds): This section contains documents regarding the Design System website and your use of it.
- [Back to top](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/back-to-top): The back to top component helps people quickly return to the top of a long page.
- [Breadcrumb](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/breadcrumb): Breadcrumbs show someone where they are in an appâ€™s hierarchy and provide a secondary method of navigating back to parent pages.
- [Card](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/card): Cards are containers used to display structured information or interactive content.
- [Checkbox](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/checkbox): Use checkboxes as part of a form, in dialogs or in control areas such as filters or settings.
- [Classification banner](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/classification-banner): Classification banners are used to show the data classification (also known as protective marking) of an app.
- [Data entity](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/data-entity): The data entity component displays a group of related data in a consistent and easy to consume way.
- [Footer](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/footer): Footers are placed at the bottom of the page and can be used for additional links not found in the main navigation.
- [Hero](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/hero): A large banner found at the top of page used to introduce page content, provide key actions and add personality.
- [Loading indicator](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/loading-indicator): Loading indicators help inform users that a request is being processed. Radial and linear indicators provide flexibility in design.
- [Radio button](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/radio): Radio buttons let people select a single option from a list.
- [Search bar](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/search-bar): A search bar is a special input field that allows users to search for information using keywords or phrases.
- [Skeleton](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/skeleton): Skeleton loading states are representations of the shape of content that help inform users that a specific type of component is loading.
- [Stepper](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/stepper): A stepper is a visual representation of a user's progress through a predefined set of steps in a linear process.
- [Switch](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/switch): Switches are used to quickly toggle an option on or off.
- [Tabs](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tabs): Tabs let users navigate between content within the same context. Tabs organise complex layouts by separating content into multiple sections.
- [Tooltip](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/tooltip): Tooltips provide helpful information when the cursor hovers over an element or when focus is applied.
- [Top navigation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/components/top-navigation): Top navigation sits across the top of the page. It includes the app name, search bar, main navigation and secondary links.
- [Cookies Policy](https://design.sis.gov.uk/icds/cookies-policy): Cookies Policy for the Intelligence Community Design System.
- [Design principles](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started/design-principles): Follow our community design principles.
- [Get started](https://design.sis.gov.uk/get-started): Use the Design System and UI Kit to create accessible, usable and consistent apps and services for the United Kingdom Intelligence Community.
- [Privacy Policy](https://design.sis.gov.uk/icds/privacy-policy): Privacy Policy for the Intelligence Community Design System.
- [App errors](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/app-errors): App errors are shown when a problem occurs that the user has no control over.
- [Form layout](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/form-layout): A simple layout for a form helps to make it easier to complete and allows users to focus on the content of the questions.
- [Form validation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/form-validation): Form validation checks that the information provided is correct and helps the user to fix any problems.
- [Patterns](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns): This section introduces our common design patterns.
- [Success messages](https://design.sis.gov.uk/patterns/success): Success messages inform the user of a successful outcome.
- [Elevation](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/elevation)
- [Focus indicator](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/focus-indicator)
- [Icons](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/icons)
- [Layout and spacing](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/layout-spacing): Common layout and spacing create consistency across pages and enable the rapid creation of new pages.
- [Motion](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/motion)
- [Templates](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/templates): Follow these common layout templates to apply frequently used navigation patterns to your app designs.
- [Typography](https://design.sis.gov.uk/styles/typography)
- [Testing with assistive technologies](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/testing/assistive-tech-testing): Don't rely on users of assistive technology to do the testing for you.
- [Testing for accessibility](https://design.sis.gov.uk/accessibility/testing): This section introduces you to different types of accessibility testing.
- [Template](https://design.sis.gov.uk/template)
